title: Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (Combined MELD)
description: Offers multiple versions of MELD for liver transplant planning and end-stage liver disease severity assessment

parameters.name: inr
parameters.description: International Normalized Ratio (INR) for prothrombin time

parameters.name: sodium
parameters.description: Serum sodium in mEq/L (required for MELD-Na and MELD 3.0)

parameters.name: albumin
parameters.description: Serum albumin in g/dL (required for MELD 3.0)

parameters.name: age
parameters.description: Patient age in years (required for MELD 3.0)

parameters.name: dialysis_twice_in_week
parameters.description: Patient received dialysis at least twice in the past week

result.name: meld_score
result.description: MELD score indicating severity of liver disease and transplant priority

ranges.interpretation: Mild liver disease with low 90-day mortality risk (<2%). Generally not considered for liver transplantation unless specific indications present.
Moderate liver disease with intermediate mortality risk (6-20%). May be considered for liver transplantation evaluation depending on clinical circumstances.
Severe liver disease with high mortality risk (>20%). Strong indication for liver transplantation evaluation. MELD ≥15 is generally the threshold for transplant consideration.
Very severe liver disease with very high mortality risk (>50%). High priority for liver transplantation. Close monitoring and intensive management required.
Critical liver disease with extremely high mortality risk (>80%). Highest priority for liver transplantation. Consider intensive care management and urgent transplant evaluation.

references: Kamath PS, Wiesner RH, Malinchoc M, Kremers W, Therneau TM, Kosberg CL, et al. A model to predict survival in patients with end-stage liver disease. Hepatology. 2001 Feb;33(2):464-70. doi: 10.1053/jhep.2001.22172.

Wiesner R, Edwards E, Freeman R, Harper A, Kim R, Kamath P, et al. Model for end-stage liver disease (MELD) and allocation of donor livers. Gastroenterology. 2003 Jan;124(1):91-6. doi: 10.1053/gast.2003.50016.

Kim WR, Biggins SW, Kremers WK, Wiesner RH, Kamath PS, Benson JT, et al. Hyponatremia and mortality among patients on the liver-transplant waiting list. N Engl J Med. 2008 Sep 4;359(10):1018-26. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa0801209.
Kwong AJ, Ebel NH, Kim WR, Lake JR, Smith JM, Schladt DP, et al. OPTN/SRTR 2021 Annual Data Report: Liver. Am J Transplant. 2023 Feb;23(2 Suppl 1):S178-S263. doi: 10.1016/j.ajt.2023.02.006.

Kim WR, Mannalithara A, Heimbach JK, Kamath PS, Asrani SK, Biggins SW, et al. MELD 3.0: The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease Updated for the Modern Era. Gastroenterology. 2021 Dec;161(6):1887-1895.e4. doi: 10.1053/j.gastro.2021.08.050.
formula: Version-specific formulas: Original MELD = 3.78×ln(bilirubin) + 11.2×ln(INR) + 9.57×ln(creatinine) + 6.43; MELD-Na incorporates sodium; MELD 3.0 includes albumin, age, and sex adjustments
notes: MELD 3.0 is the current standard for organ transplantation (effective 2023)
Use most recent lab values within 48 hours
Maximum creatinine of 4.0 mg/dL used in calculations if higher
Minimum values: bilirubin 1.0 mg/dL, creatinine 1.0 mg/dL, INR 1.0
Sodium clamped between 125-137 mEq/L for MELD-Na calculations
Patients under 12 years should use PELD (Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease) score
OPTN accepts maximum submitted score of 40
Score should be recalculated as lab values change
Different formulas apply for ages 12-18 vs ≥18 years in MELD 3.0
